column1: Vlissingen (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈvlɪsɪŋə(n)] (listen); Zeelandic: Vlissienge; historical name in English: Flushing) is a municipality and a city in the southwestern Netherlands on the former island of Walcheren. With its strategic location between the Scheldt river and the North Sea
column2: Vlissingen has been an important harbour for centuries. It was granted city rights in 1315. In the 17th century Vlissingen was a main harbour for ships of the Dutch East India Company (VOC). It is also known as the birthplace of Admiral Michiel de Ruyter.

column1: Vlissingen is mainly noted for the yards on the Scheldt where most of the ships of the Royal Netherlands Navy (Koninklijke Marine) are built.

column2: 400-year history into the third-most important port of the Netherlands. The Counts of Holland
column4: and Zeeland had the first harbours dug. Over the centuries
column5: Vlissingen developed into a hub for fishing
column8: privateering and the slave trade.  Under the Treaty of Nonsuch in 1585
column9: English garrisons were stationed here and at Brill to keep these ports out of Spanish hands. The towns were sold back to the Dutch in 1616.   During the heyday of the Dutch Golden Age
column10: ships from Vlissingen set sail for the various outposts of the Dutch colonial empire and contributed to the world power of The Seven Provinces.

column1: The history of Vlissingen was also marked by invasion
column2: oppression and bombardments. Because of its strategic position at the mouth of the Schelde
column3: the most important passageway to Antwerp
column8: the Germans and the Spanish. Floods have also been a constant threat. Vlissingen declined during the 18th century. The Napoleonic Wars were particularly disastrous. After 1870
column9: the economy revived after the construction of new docks and the Walcheren canal
column10: the arrival of the railway and the establishment of the shipyard called De Schelde. The Second World War interrupted this growth. The city was heavily damaged by shelling and inundation but was captured and liberated by British Commandos of 4th Special Service Brigade on 3 November 1944.

column1: The city was rebuilt after the war. In the 1960s
column2: the seaport and industrial area of Vlissingen-Oost developed and flourished. Now this area is the economic driving force behind central Zeeland
column3: generating many thousands of jobs. Nowadays approx. 50
column4: 000 ships annually from all corners of the world pass through the Schelde.

column1: The derivation of the name Vlissingen is unclear
column2: though most scholars relate the name to the word fles ("bottle") in one way or another.
when saint Willibrord landed in Vlissingen with a bottle in the 7th century
column3: he shared its contents with the beggars he found there while trying to convert them. A miracle occurred
column5: when the contents of the bottle did not diminish. When the bishop realised the beggars did not want to listen to his words
column6: he gave them his bottle. After that
column7: he supposedly called the city Flessinghe.

column1: Another source states that the name had its origins in an old ferry-service house
column2: on which a bottle was attached by way of a sign. The monk Jacob van Dreischor
column4: then apparently called the ferry-house het veer aan de Flesse ("the ferry at the Bottle"). Because many cities in the region later received the appendix -inge

column2: the name was derived from the Danish word Vles

column1: The eastern cape of Novaya Zemlya
column2: Cape Flissingsky was named after the city in 1596 by Willem Barentsz.

column1: Vlissingen was historically called "Flushing" in English. In the 17th century Vlissingen was important enough to be a town that English speakers referred to and that had acquired its own English name. For example
column2: Samuel Pepys referred to the town as "Flushing" in his diaries. In 1673 Sir William Temple referred to Vlissingen as "Flushing" once and "Flussingue" twice in his book about the Netherlands. Some English writers in the Netherlands also used the Dutch name.
originally a Dutch colonial village founded in 1645 and now part of Queens
column4: was first called Vlissingen after the town in the Netherlands. The English settlers who also came to live in the village shortened the name to "Vlissing" by 1657 and then began to call it by its English name "Flushing." The Anglicisation of "Vlissingen" into "Flushing" did not occur after the conquest of New Netherland
column5: but in England well before then. This village was the site of the Flushing Remonstrance.

column1: The village of Flushing in Cornwall was also named after Vlissingen. Originally named Nankersey
column2: the village was given its name by Dutch engineers from Vlissingen in the Netherlands who built the three main quays in the village. Michigan and Ohio in the US have villages called Flushing as well.

column1: Vlissingen has a temperate oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb) that is milder than the rest of the Netherlands due to its more southern location on the coast. It is approximately 1.5 degrees Celsius warmer annually than Groningen in the northeast. It is also one of the sunniest cities in the Netherlands
column2: receiving approximately 180 more sunshine hours than Maastricht in the southeast. Its all-time record is 36.8 °C set on 27 July 2018 and -18.9 °C on 21 February 1956

column1: Vlissingen is the setting for part of Arthur Ransome's children's adventure novel We Didn't Mean to Go to Sea.
Vlissingen is also the setting for most of the film The Fourth Man.
Vlissingen is also the hometown of Mynheer Claessens and his daughter Johanna
